About Us.What Is FFFJapan?: FridaysForFuture is a movement that started in August 2018, when 15 year old Greta Thunberg sat in front of the Swedish parliament every school day for three weeks, to protest against the lack of action on the climate crisis. Her actions evoked young people’s empathies  and the movement soon went viral. In the one week action “Global Week for Future” in September 2019, more than 7 million people from around the world joined the strikes and demanded action towards climate change. There are many young people who support this movement in Japan as well. In February of 2019, the FridaysForFuture in Japan started from Tokyo. Ever since the start, our movement is growing little by little in Japan with the youth at its heart.
About Us.History1_Title: The start of the movement in Japan
About Us.History1: In February of 2019, the Fridays For Future Japan movement started with student interns for environment NGOs as the central role. 15 people gathered in front of the parliament on the 22nd of February, surrounded by more numbers of media journalists than activists.
About Us.History2_Title: The first global strike in Japan
About Us.History2: On the 15th of March 2019, we had our first march in Tokyo and Kyoto that coincided with the Global Climate Strike. The number of participants was 300 people! (20 times the number of people from February)
About Us.History3: We had 450 participants for our third march on the 24th of May 2019 held in Tokyo and Kyoto. The numbers were small compared to the strikes in other countries, but the slow growth of numbers in Japan gave us hope.
About Us.History4: Our movement slowly spread to Nagoya, Fukuoka, Naha, Nasu, and other regions. The Global Climate March held in Japan (and around the world) on the 20th of September had a total of 5000 participants from 24 prefectures and 27 locations.
About Us.History5_Title: Branches for Fridays For Future are set up in various places in Japan
About Us.History5: Branches for Fridays For Future are set up in various places in Japan. In the November strike(our first real strike) of 2019, people from 25 prefectures and 28 regions raised their voices, and branches are still developing all over Japan.
About Us.History6_Title: Student Climate Emergency Summit is held!
About Us.History6: In February of 2020, we held the Student Climate Emergency Summit in Shibuya, Tokyo to provide an opportunity for students to learn about climate change, connect, and take action. We had around 100 participants from all over Japan and we had many specialists such as Mr. Seita Emori from the National Institute for Environmental Studies as guest speakers.
